item.title: Chirp Spread Spectrum Explained
item.description:
üåÄ What Is Chirp Spread Spectrum?

Chirp Spread Spectrum (CSS) is a wireless modulation technique that encodes data using signals called chirps ‚Äî waveforms that sweep across a range of frequencies over time. Think of it like sonar: instead of sending a single tone, a device sends a sweeping signal that changes pitch as it moves. These chirps can be increasing (up-chirp) or decreasing (down-chirp) in frequency.

This sweeping behavior makes CSS highly resistant to interference and noise. Even if parts of the signal are lost or distorted, the receiver can still reconstruct the message. That‚Äôs why CSS is ideal for long-range, low-power communication in challenging environments.

We believe everyone deserves a way to communicate that’s free from corporate control, surveillance, and dependency on fragile infrastructure. That’s why we‚Äôre building a decentralized mesh network - one that can work even when the internet doesn’t.

item.title: What is the Mesh?
item.description:
The mesh is a community-powered communication system that uses inexpensive LoRa radios to connect people without relying on cell towers or internet access.

Several open-source applications can run on this LoRa-based mesh ‚Äî but Meshtastic currently has the widest adoption and most active community, making it the easiest way to get started.

It‚Äôs designed for off-grid messaging, emergency preparedness, outdoor adventures, and community resilience. By forming a decentralized mesh network, devices relay messages across multiple nodes ‚Äî extending coverage far beyond the range of a single device.
